title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Knicks Stave Off 76ers Behind Ewing's Colossal 44-Point Effort**

PHILADELPHIA (AP) — On a night where offensive artistry met sheer will, Patrick Ewing delivered a performance for the ages, carrying the New York Knicks to a bruising 110-103 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

This was not merely a win; it was a testament to one man's dominance. Ewing was unstoppable, pouring in a monumental 44 points and grabbing 14 rebounds, imposing his will on the game from the opening tip to the final, decisive moments. The 76ers, despite a valiant 30-point effort from Allen Iverson, had no answer for the Knicks' center, who operated with ruthless efficiency in the paint.

The game was a classic Eastern Conference battle, a physical grind that saw the Knicks build a lead that the young Iverson and the 76ers could never quite overcome. Every time Philadelphia threatened to close the gap, Ewing had a response—a thunderous dunk, a graceful turnaround jumper, or a powerful put-back. His 44-point eruption was the engine of the Knicks' offense, a force so singular it defined every possession.

While Ewing's brilliance rightfully commands the headlines, support came from Allan Houston, who added 19 points to help balance the attack. For the 76ers, Derrick Coleman’s 19 points and 13 rebounds were ultimately overshadowed by the historic night from the opposing pivot.

In the end, the story was simple and profound: Patrick Ewing was a force of nature. On this night in Philadelphia, one of the game's greats reached a zenith, shouldering the load and writing his own legendary chapter in the Knicks' fierce rivalry with the 76ers.
